events.title: Birth
events.summary: Lully was born into a Tuscan family of millers in Florence, where little is known about his early education and musical training. He was introduced to music by a Franciscan friar, who also taught him to play the guitar and violin.
events.fun_version: Lully was born into a family of millers in Florence, where details about his early education are as scarce as a pizza without cheese. He was introduced to music by a Franciscan friar, who taught him how to rock out on the guitar and violin.

events.title: Service to Mademoiselle de Montpensier
events.summary: Dressed as Harlequin, Lully showcased his talents during Mardi Gras, which attracted the attention of Roger de Lorraine. He entered the service of Mademoiselle de Montpensier as her chamber boy, honing his musical skills during this period.
events.fun_version: Dressed as Harlequin, Lully danced around during Mardi Gras like he was auditioning for a role in a circus—clowns and tigers not included. He caught the eye of Roger de Lorraine and joined the glamorous life of Mademoiselle de Montpensier as her chamber boy, honing his musical skills during this period.

events.title: Royal Composer
events.summary: By February 1653, Lully gained the favor of Louis XIV, participating in the Ballet royal de la nuit. Just over a month later, he was appointed royal composer for instrumental music, making himself indispensable with his works for court ballets.
events.fun_version: In February 1653, Lully gained the favor of Louis XIV by participating in the Ballet royal de la nuit. A month later, he wasn't just writing music; he was practically the musical fairy godmother of the court ballets, as he became the royal composer for instrumental music, making himself indispensable to the court.

events.title: Ballet du Temps
events.summary: Performed at the Louvre on November 30, 1654, this ballet is an early representation of Lully's work in court ballet, integrating dance and music in a way that resonated with audiences and marked a pivotal development in the genre.
events.fun_version: Performed at the Louvre on November 30, 1654, this ballet is an early representation of Lully's work in court ballet, with dancers so graceful they made swans look like clumsy ducks, integrating dance and music like a new smoothie recipe. This marked a pivotal development in the genre.

events.title: Ballet des plaisirs
events.summary: This ballet was staged at the Louvre on February 4, 1655, demonstrating the collaborative efforts between Lully and text writers, which helped elevate the genre and establish Lully's reputation as a composer for the French court.
events.fun_version: Back in 1655, when the Louvre was just a fancy house for artsy folks, Lully decided to throw a ballet bash on February 4th! It was like a dance party where Lully and his text-writing pals juggled words and pirouettes to elevate the ballet genre and establish Lully's reputation as a serious composer for the French court. Imagine the court’s reaction - they probably were twirling in their chairs!

events.title: Marriage to Madeleine Lambert
events.summary: Lully married Madeleine Lambert, the daughter of a renowned writer and composer, in a significant event reflecting his elevated status in society. The couple had six surviving children together.
events.fun_version: Lully tied the knot with Madeleine Lambert, who happens to be the daughter of someone who could probably write a bestseller on how to be famous. Their wedding was a significant event reflecting his elevated status in society and was such a big deal that even the cake had a moment of fame. And guess what? They managed to have six surviving children!

events.title: Psyché
events.summary: A tragi-comedy, this opera was performed on January 17, 1671, at the Théâtre des Tuileries. It exemplifies Lully’s shift towards opera and reflects the collaborative spirit with notable playwrights of his time.
events.fun_version: Picture the performers at the Théâtre des Tuileries on January 17, 1671, trying to create an opera that leaves audiences both entertained and thoughtful. That’s Lully for you, making a shift towards opera while collaborating with notable playwrights, probably discussing among themselves the best ways to blend laughter and music!

events.title: Director of the Académie Royale de Musique
events.summary: After a successful career, Lully became the director of the Académie Royale de Musique around 1672. He produced a new opera almost every year during his tenure, solidifying his position in the world of French opera.
events.fun_version: After enjoying a successful career, Lully hit the high notes as the director of the Académie Royale de Musique around 1672. He produced a new opera almost every year during his tenure, cranking them out faster than a baker does croissants—one for nearly every year of his reign! Truly, he secured the title of “King of French Opera”!

events.title: Cadmus et Hermione
events.summary: This tragedy, staged on April 27, 1673, at the tennis court of Bel-Air, showcases Lully's commitment to dramatic storytelling through music, which influenced the future of French opera.
events.fun_version: On April 27, 1673, in what can only be described as the most dramatic tennis match ever held at Bel-Air, Lully decided to swap his tennis racket for a conductor's baton. With his commitment to dramatic storytelling through music, who knew he could score more points for French opera than for actual tennis? This performance truly influenced the future of French opera!

events.title: Alceste ou le Triomphe d'Alcide
events.summary: Performed on January 19, 1674, this tragedy reflects Lully's flair for combining narrative and music, presenting a powerful adaptation of dramatic themes in French opera.
events.fun_version: So, on January 19, 1674, when everyone was busy debating the color of their wigs, Lully decided it was the perfect day to mix music and drama like a chef preparing an avant-garde soufflé. This piece is a dramatic opera that even the stuffiest aristocrat would appreciate—it's like the perfect blend of surprise and sophistication! This tragedy showcases Lully's talent for weaving narrative with music, delivering a potent adaptation of dramatic themes in French opera.

events.title: Isis
events.summary: Titled tragedy with ballet entries, it premiered on January 5, 1677, at St-Germain-en-Laye, marking a synthesis of opera and dance that characterized Lully’s later works.
events.fun_version: Once upon a time in the land of fancy tights and elegant pirouettes, a ballet titled 'tragedy' took the stage on January 5, 1677, in St-Germain-en-Laye. It was the splendid offspring of opera and dance!

events.title: Te Deum
events.summary: This notable work was performed at Fontainebleau on September 9, 1677. It is among Lully's significant contributions to sacred music, showcasing his mastery in composition and ability to convey religious themes.
events.fun_version: So, back in 1677, a bunch of folks gathered at Fontainebleau to listen to what Lully considered music, a notable work that is among his significant contributions to sacred music. Who wouldn’t enjoy a little divine intervention with their 17th-century soundtrack? Lully was showcasing his mastery in composition and his ability to convey religious themes.

events.title: Motets à deux chœurs pour la Chapelle du roi
events.summary: Published in 1684, this collection features grand motets written for the royal chapel, often performed during significant religious occasions. Lully built upon the existing genre, contributing to its popularity and development in the French music tradition.
events.fun_version: Published in 1684, this collection features grand motets written for the royal chapel, often performed during significant religious occasions. Imagine a group of royal musicians, dressed in their finest tights, serenading the king and queen! Lully built upon the existing genre, contributing to its popularity and development in the French music tradition.

events.title: Acis et Galatée
events.summary: A pastorale héroïque presented on September 6, 1686, at the chateau of Anet, this work encapsulates Lully’s inventive approach to opera and the integration of scenic effects.
events.fun_version: A pastor with a heroic cape made a grand entrance on September 6, 1686, at the chateau of Anet. This wasn’t your average sermon; it was Lully’s innovative opera that combined stunning visual effects with dramatic storytelling! Imagine effects so good that even the curtains were applauding!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Lully suffered from gangrene due to an injury to his foot sustained during a performance. He declined surgery that could have saved him, leading to his death caused by the spread of the infection.
events.fun_version: Lully had a rather unfortunate case of gangrene, and not the type you can cure with a good foot massage! After a spirited dance on stage, his foot decided it wanted to embrace infection instead of applause. He could have escaped this messy situation with surgery, but ultimately, he lost the battle to the infection.

works.title: Ballet de la Revente des Habits, LWV 5
Les plaisirs de l'île enchantée, LWV 22
Le triomphe de Bacchus dans les Indes, LWV 30
Les fêtes de l'Amour et de Bacchus, LWV 47
Ballet du temple de la paix, LWV 69
Marches militaires et airs pour le carrousel de Monseigneur, LWV 72
